Derek James wrote:

>On 9/30/05, John Arrowwood <jarrowwx@...> wrote:
>  
>
>>Out of curiosity, and to spark debate,
>>
>>how can this (below) be expanded to include the general case of a
>>generalized device that is capable of 'learning' and developing it's
>>own strategy?  That is, it 'learns' the rules, it develops a strategy,
>>and some of what is 'learned' in one game is transferrable to another
>>game.
>>
>>Or is that not the ultimate goal?
>>    
>>
>
>Well the *ultimate* goal is a race of sentient machines that usurp and
>enslave us, but in a nice sort of way. :)
>  
>
Perhaps then we should work on a race of *super* sentient machines to 
defeat these other machines and... oh no, hold on. As is oft said on 
slashdot, I for one welcome our new [insert technology under discussion] 
overlords.

>Seriously, a very general game playing system that is able to be
>taught the rules of nearly any board game and learn strategies through
>incremental play...now *that* I do think is currently beyond the state
>of the art.
>  
>
This requires understanding of the games being played, which in turn 
requires sentience, err probably, I think. Or do I mean conciousness? On 
the other hand if you have super fast CPU's available that can play all 
[board] games by employing minimax or whatever then you don't need to 
understand the game and you don't have to evaulate your opponent 'on the 
fly'. In fact all games then become pointless as the outcome is always 
predetermined. Of course some games (e.g. Go) have such a large number 
of possible paths that must be evaluated that it's unlikely any computer 
would ever be able to play in such a deterministic way.

Colin
